text: The addiction of English to acronyms. What is this new measure of performance I am seeing called TTFP? Total-Tera-Floating-Point operations per unit time? I even got to google it before understanding that it is my good old friend time-to-first-plot

text:
It is also that we did not adopt that we should allow snippets or macros in typing.

Im sure any community has its shibbolethic qualities, but hopefully people outside can pick up on it without too much pain ><

text: Overuse of acronyms in academic papers is one of my biggest pet peeves

elements.text: Overuse of acronyms in academic papers is one of my biggest pet peeves

text: IHABICNRWTSF

elements.text: IHABICNRWTSF

text: IHTFP

elements.text: IHTFP

text: OMGWAATAPLSSENDHELP

elements.text: OMGWAATAPLSSENDHELP

text: The worst usage og acronyms is when it arises because people are too lazy to think of real names for things.

elements.text: The worst usage og acronyms is when it arises because people are too lazy to think of real names for things.

text:
idk, i think worse still is the ones with really forced acronyms to make puns. Especially in academic papers.
It was cute the first time.
It is less the 5th.

MAML (Model Agnostic Meta Learning) pronounced Mammal is pretty aweful.
with a follow up work called Reptile (not an acronym, just a name that is only meaningful if you get the previous punn).
MANN is another one from that general field (metalearning/few shot learning), only here the MA is unrelated: it is Memory-Augmented Neural Network.

text: <https://abracadabra.mit.edu/>

I'd have to look it up but I'm convinced most acronyms take more time to read and understand than the full expression. Because we can easily read  long words at a glance, but an acronym always has to be mentally translated, unless it is used so widely that it stops being an abbreviation and starts being its own "word".

elements.text: I'd have to look it up but I'm convinced most acronyms take more time to read and understand than the full expression. Because we can easily read  long words at a glance, but an acronym always has to be mentally translated, unless it is used so widely that it stops being an abbreviation and starts being its own "word".

text: I think they serve a very useful purpose--documents in certain domains, and conversations about things, would be 10x as long without them. The problem really is people don't know their audience and spell out the acronym when it's first used and/or include an appendix. I mean the whole existence of jargon in general, which acronyms are just a particular case of, is to make communication more efficient but jargon necessarily, by definition really, has to be context-dependent. So here in this conversation we can talk about Three Letter Acronyms (TLA) henceforth but yeah it's not a great idea to just throw TLA into a conversation that's not already about acronyms without defining/re-defining it.

So here in this conversation we can talk about Three Letter Acronyms (TLA) henceforth but yeah it's not a great idea to just throw TLA into a conversation that's not already about acronyms without defining/re-defining it.

text: Maybe to ease the burden there could be systems that help out. E.g. in Discourse maybe it would be possible to hover over "TTFP" and have it show a tooltip "Time To First Plot", either because somewhere someone defined it (in a pattern like [expansion] ([acronym])) or maybe even through some neat NLP (natural language processing) technique that employs context somehow. Of course if you have some conversation involving nonlinear programming being used in natural language processing, well, it's going to be confusing no matter what. :stuck_out_tongue:

text: I sometimes read through my twitter feed and can't parse a single tweet because they use 20% acronymes I don't know... Maybe also because I get tweets from quite a lot of areas... The tweets from us politics/law/business are sometimes completely unreadable to me, since I know very few acronymes from that area^^

text: Take away: I usually try to avoid acronymes as much as possible to make things easy for beginners in the field - especially on discourse, github & twitter where I don't know my audience

text:
Acronyms save typing time, and line space. People like typing less if possible, and reading smaller paragraphs when possible. 

This is why acronyms are everywhere in online communities. There’s a balance to be struck for sure, but imo the correct balance is not eliminating acronyms.

elements.text:

This is why acronyms are everywhere in online communities. There’s a balance to be struck for sure, but imo the correct balance is not eliminating acronyms.

text: It'd be nice if something like <https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/reddit-spacex-acronym-exp/ifdpkdjglcngbfhpmckkffhbabeanapd?hl=en-GB> existed but in a more general way, automatically picking up acronyms as you browse and giving its best guess of definitions based on history and context.

attachments.title: Reddit SpaceX Acronym Expander
attachments.text: This extension expands acronyms on the SpaceX Reddit page for easier reading

existed but in a more general way, automatically picking up acronyms as you browse and giving its best guess of definitions based on history and context.

text: Acronyms are pretty context specific, so  a general acronym expander sounds like it’s be pretty cutting edge, though perhaps possible with proper semantic modelling.

elements.text: Acronyms are pretty context specific, so  a general acronym expander sounds like it’s be pretty cutting edge, though perhaps possible with proper semantic modelling.

text: I think it could definitely give ranked suggestions which one could thumbs up/down to improve the suggestions. It could be auto-crowdsourced too, in a way, if individuals' data was centralized (obviously some privacy issues to be dealt with there).

elements.text: I think it could definitely give ranked suggestions which one could thumbs up/down to improve the suggestions. It could be auto-crowdsourced too, in a way, if individuals' data was centralized (obviously some privacy issues to be dealt with there).

text:
> so  a general acronym expander sounds like it's be pretty cutting edge

Contextual language modelling has been a task in NLP for decades.
Language modelling in general is "easy" in that very simple models work very well.

The fact that this is domain specific might make it harder, but this is 2021. We can just throw more data at it, so even narrow subdomains are covered.

And you can write some heuristic rules. (high precision, low recall. So only discovers easy case, but gets them all right) to do training set generation.

I would say less "cutting edge" and more "suitable for a bachelor's thesis project". Challenging, but achievable. Publishable in the ACL demo track.

And you can write some heuristic rules. (high precision, low recall. So only discovers easy case, but gets them all right) to do training set generation.

I would say less "cutting edge" and more "suitable for a bachelor's thesis project". Challenging, but achievable. Publishable in the ACL demo track.
